Pakistani Lieutenant-General Asim Bajwa addresses journalists in Islamabad on Tuesday, giving details of Kulbhushan Yadav (on screen), who is suspected of being an Indian spy.— PHOTO: AFP

He said he used to report to an R&AW officer named Anil Kumar Gupta.

RAW officials weren’t available for comment. However, the MEA said that the video has “no basis in fact.” “That the individual claims to make the statements of his own free will not only challenges credulity but clearly indicates tutoring,” the MEA said, asking Pakistan to provide consular access to Mr. Yadav. It is necessary to find out how he landed in Pakistan “under unexplained circumstances,” the ministry said.

The former Foreign Secretary, Kanwal Sibal, told The Hindu that the entire sequence of events leading up to the arrest indicated Pakistani officials wanted to push back on allegations of terror.

“Pakistan wants to get some propaganda advantage as the U.S. has stepped up pressure after the Pathankot attack. Pakistan has accused the person of being a serving naval officer. This is incredible as no intelligence agency sends serving naval officers with passports.”
title: India rejects ‘spy confession’
